thread.title: Aircraft deployed as Wadbilliga Park fire spans 19 hectares
thread.title_full: Aircraft deployed as Wadbilliga Park fire spans 19 hectares

author: cookie:PNIJfdCairqyvwp
title: Aircraft deployed as Wadbilliga Park fire spans 19 hectares
text:
A bush fire in a NSW South Coast national park has expanded to 91 hectares.
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Rural Fire Service public liaison officer Marty Webster told Bega District News crews were taking the fire very seriously and were throwing all the appropriate resources at it.
The fire was located north of Yowrie, south of Belowra, and approximately 20 kilometres north west of Cobargo in Wadbilliga National Park.
"The fire is burning in really challenging country, so it's hard to get good containment," Mr Webster said.
"The multi-agency response has slowed its progression in the challenging and hot conditions."
Mr Webster said crews would be battling the blaze throughout the night with the "intent to keep it as small as possible".
Heavy machinery was deployed to prepare a number of contingency plans to give firefighters a range of options.
On the morning of Thursday, January 8, the multi-agency effort continued on the NSW South Coast as firefighters battled what was then a 19 hectare national park fire.
Far South Coast RFS district coordinator Chris Anderson said the fire was burning in rugged remote and inaccessible terrain in Wadbilliga National Park.
"We've currently got aircraft up over the top of it actively water-bombing the fire" Mr Anderson told Bega District News on Thursday, January 8.
"Firefighters from RFS, National Parks and Wildlife Service and Forestry Corporation are all actively on the ground at this fire.
"We're preparing for the next few days in case the fire does move out of there.
"But like I said, we've got approximately seven aircraft actively bombing this fire at the moment to keep it to the smaller size.
"We want people to keep up to date with this fire via RFS social media channels, the media, and the Hazards Near Me app."
While the cause of the fire was still under investigation, Mr Anderson noted that there had been a lot of lightning over the region in the past few days.
"We just want people to be mindful that we had a significant amount of lightning over the weekend," he said.
"Fires from lightning can pop up days and days after the event.
"So just keep an eye on your properties."
